1.q_string: A 1000 g sample of \(\mathrm{NaOH}\) contains 3 moles of \(\mathrm{O}\) atom, what is the purity of \(\mathrm{NaOH} ?\)
The % loss in weight after heating a pure sample of potassium chlorate (Molecular weight \(=122.5 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{mol})\) will be:
If the percentage of water of crystallization in \(\mathrm{MgSO}_{4} \cdot \mathrm{xH}_{2} \mathrm{O}\) is \(13 \%\), then what is the value of \(x\) ?
Mole fraction of ethanol in ethanol-water mixture is \(0.25\). Hence, the percentage concentration of ethanol by weight of the mixture is:

If the water molecules in \(1.0 \mathrm{~g}\) of water were distributes uniformly over the surface of earth, If there are \(6.5 \times 10^{-\mathrm{x}}\) such molecules would there be in \(1.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\) of earth's surface, then what is the value of \(\mathrm{x}\) ?

A mineral consists of an equimolar mixture of the carbonates of two bivalent metals. One metal is present to the extent of \(15.0 \%\) by weight. \(3.0\) \(\mathrm{g}\) of the mineral on heating lost \(1.10 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{CO}_{2}\). The percent by weight of other metal is :
The simplest formula of a compound containing \(50 \%\) of element \(\mathrm{X}\) (Atomic mass \(=10\) ) and \(50 \%\) of the element Y (Atomic mass \(=20\) ) by weight is:

An aqueous solution of \(\mathrm{NaOH}\) having density \(1.1 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{dm}^{3}\) contains \(0.02\) mole fraction of \(\mathrm{NaOH}\). The \% by mass of \(\mathrm{NaOH}\) in the solution is :

A mixture of \(\mathrm{CuSO}_{4} .5 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\) and \(\mathrm{MgSO}_{4} .7 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\) was heated until all the water was driven off. If \(5.0 \mathrm{~g}\) of mixture gave \(3 \mathrm{~g}\) of anhydrous salt, what was the percentage by mass of \(\mathrm{CuSO}_{4} \cdot 5 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\) in the original mixture?

Two beakers \(\mathrm{A}\) and B present in a closed vessel. Beaker A contains \(152.4 \mathrm{~g}\) aqueous solution of urea, containing \(12 \mathrm{~g}\) of urea. Beaker B contains \(196.2 \mathrm{~g}\) glucose solution, containing \(18 \mathrm{~g}\) of glucose. Both the solutions allowed to attain the equilibrium. Determine weight \% of glucose in its solution is at equilibrium.

The molality of \(1 \mathrm{~L}\) solution with \(\mathrm{x} \% \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}\) is 9 . The weight of the solvent present in the solution is \(910 \mathrm{~g}\). The value of \(\mathrm{x}\) is:

\(\mathrm{n}_{1} \mathrm{~g}\) of substance \(\mathrm{X}\) reacts with \(\mathrm{n}_{2} \mathrm{~g}\) of substance \(\mathrm{Y}\) to form \(\mathrm{m}_{1} \mathrm{~g}\) of substance \(\mathrm{R}\) and \(\mathrm{m}_{2} \mathrm{~g}\) of substance of \(\mathrm{S}\). This reaction can be represented as \(\mathrm{X}+\mathrm{Y} \rightarrow \mathrm{R}+\mathrm{S}\). The relation which can be established in the amounts of the reactants and the products will be:
Cortisone is a molecular substance containing 21 atoms of carbon per molecule. The mass percentage of carbon in cortisone is \(69.98 \%\). Its molar mass is:
The sodium salt of methyl orange has \(7 \%\) sodium. What is the minimum molecular weight of the compound?
Mole fraction of ethanol and water mixture is \(0.25\). Hence, percentage concentration of ethanol by weight of mixture is:
A spherical ball of radius \(7 \mathrm{~cm}\) contains \(56 \%\) iron. If density is \(1.4 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{cc}\), the number of moles of \(\mathrm{F}\) e present approximately is :

Assertion: The balancing of chemical equations is based on the law of conservation of mass.

Reason: Total mass of reactants is equal to total mass of products.
q_option: Assertion and reason both are correct statements and reason is correct explanation for assertion.
Assertion and reason both are correct statements but reason is not correct explanation for assertion.
Assertion is correct statement but reason is wrong statement.
Assertion is wrong statement but reason is correct statement.

1.q_string: Which of the following is a suitable example for illustrating the law of conservation of mass? (Atomic mass of \(\mathrm{O}=16 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{mol}, \mathrm{H}=1 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{mole}\) )
q_option: \(18 \mathrm{~g}\) of water is formed by the combination of \(16 \mathrm{~g}\) oxygen with \(2 \mathrm{~g}\) of hydrogen.
\(18 \mathrm{~g}\) of water in liquid state is obtained by heating \(18 \mathrm{~g}\) of ice.
\(18 \mathrm{~g}\) of water is completely converted into vapour state on heating.
\(18 \mathrm{~g}\) of water freezes at \(4^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) to give same mass of ice.

1.q_string: A salt is formed due to the reaction between an oxy acid containing chlorine and a base containing a monovalent metal of atomic mass \(\mathrm{x}\). The number of oxygen atoms in one molecule of the acid is more than the corresponding 'ic' acid. Calculate the molecular mass of the salt.

If \(40 \mathrm{~g}\) of ethyl alcohol is dissolved in \(50 \mathrm{ml}\) of water, then calculate the weight/volume percentage of ethyl alcohol present in the solution? [Density of ethyl alcohol \(=0.8 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{ml}\) ].

\(\mathrm{CaCO}_{3}+2 \mathrm{HCl} \rightarrow \mathrm{CaCl}_{2}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}+\mathrm{CO}_{2}\)

The volume of \(\mathrm{CO}_{2}\) gas formed when \(2.5 \mathrm{~g}\) calcium carbonate is dissolved in excess hydrochloric acid at \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(1 \mathrm{~atm}\) pressure is:

[1 mole of any gas at \(0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(1 \mathrm{~atm}\) pressure occupies \(22.414 \mathrm{~L}\) volume].
We have to prepare a Litre solution of 0.2 M NaOH from the available 1 M solution. What volume of 1M NaOH is required to be taken ?

A \(0.24 \mathrm{~g}\) sample of compound of oxygen and boron was found by analysis to contain \(0.096 \mathrm{~g}\) of boron and \(0.144 \mathrm{~g}\) of oxygen. Calculate the percentage composition of the compound by weight.
The hydrated salt, \(\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4} \cdot \mathrm{nH}_{2} \mathrm{O}\) undergoes \(56 \%\) loss in weight on heating and becomes anhydrous. The value of \(n\) (approx.) will be :
If a \(360 \mathrm{~mL}\) sample of helium contains \(0.25\) moles, how many molecules of chlorine gas would occupy the same volume at the same pressure and temperature?
"All gases have the same number of moles in the same volume at constant temperature and pressure:. This statments belongs to :

Statement 1: At the same temperature and pressure, 1 L of hydrogen gas and  1 L of neon gas have the same mass.

Statement 2: Equal volumes of ideal gases at the same temperature and pressure contain the same number of moles.
q_option: Both statement 1 and statement 2 are correct and statement 2 is the correct explanation of statement 1
Both statement 1 and statement 2 are correct but Statement 2 is not the correct explanation of Statement 1
Statement 1 is correct but statement 2 is incorrect
Statement 1 is incorrect but statement 2 is correct

1.q_string: In an experiment \(1.288 \mathrm{~g}\) of copper oxide was obtained from \(1.03 \mathrm{~g}\) of copper and \(0.258 \mathrm{~g}\) of oxygen. Calculate the ratio of copper and oxygen in the sample?
\(0.16 \mathrm{~g}\) of an organic compound containing sulphur produces \(0.233 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{BaSO}_{4}\). Percentage of sulphur in the compound is :

Natural abundances of \({ }^{12} \mathrm{C}\) and \({ }^{13} \mathrm{C}\) isotopes of carbon are \(99 \%\) and \(1 \%\), respectively. Assuming they only contribute to the mol. wt. of \(\mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{~F}_{4}\), the percentage of \(\mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{~F}_{4}\) having a molecular mass of 101 is:

data.test_name: Some Basic Concepts of Chemistry Test - 4
